DOCNAME: CASE OF ASSOCIATION FOR EUROPEAN INTEGRATION AND HUMAN RIGHTS AND EKIMDZHIEV v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 13;No violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . One of the principal aims of the applicant association is the protection of human rights . The second applicant is a lawyer . His practice includes acting as counsel in civil and criminal cases in the courts in GPE and representing applicants in proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . Their application is directed against LAW of DATE , a piece of legislation which presently regulates the use of special means of surveillance in GPE . The applicants do not aver that surveillance measures have in fact been ordered or implemented against them , nor that they have been indirectly involved in a surveillance measure directed against other persons . They contend that under the law as it stands they may be subjected to such measures at any point in time without any notification prior to , during , or after the said measures are applied .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW of DATE are :

“ CARDINAL . The private life of citizens shall be inviolable . Everyone shall have the right to be protected against unlawful interferences with his private and family life and against encroachments on his honour , dignity and reputation .

CARDINAL . No one may be spied on , photographed , filmed , recorded , or subjected to similar actions without his or her knowledge or despite his or her express disagreement , except in cases provided for by law . ”
“ The home shall be inviolable . No one may enter or remain in it without the consent of its inhabitant , except in the cases expressly specified by law . ”
“ CARDINAL . NORP The freedom and secret of correspondence and other communications shall be inviolable .
CARDINAL . NORP This rule may be subject to exceptions only with the permission of the judicial authorities when necessary for uncovering or preventing serious offences . ”

“ ORG shall have the right to information from state bodies or agencies on any matter of legitimate interest to them , unless the information is a state secret or a secret protected by law , or affects the rights of others . ”
“ The judiciary shall be independent . In carrying out their duties the judges , the jurors , the prosecutors and the investigators shall have regard solely to the law . ”

CARDINAL . The Special Surveillance Means Act of DATE ( „ Закон за специалните разузнавателни средства “ – “ the ORG ” ) , which presently is the principal legislative enactment regulating the use of special means of surveillance , was adopted in DATE . It underwent minor amendments in DATE and DATE , more extensive ones in DATE , and some further minor changes in DATE . Its essential provisions have however remained intact since its adoption and the account which follows is based on their present version .

CARDINAL . The ORG governs the conditions for and the manner of use of special means of surveillance , as well as the control of their use and of the results obtained thereby ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . It defines special means of surveillance as technical devices which can be used for creating photographs , audio and video recordings and marked objects , as well as the methods for operating them ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . By section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the ORG , special means of surveillance may be used when necessary to prevent or uncover serious offences ( LAW § CARDINAL of LAW of DATE defines a “ serious ” offence as one punishable by DATE imprisonment ) , if the requisite intelligence can not be obtained through other means . LAW provides that special means of surveillance may also be used for activities relating to national security .

CARDINAL . Special means of surveillance may be used against persons suspected , on the basis of the information available , of planning , committing , or having committed serious offences , or against persons who might be unwittingly involved in the above by the suspected perpetrators . Such means may also be used against persons and objects related with national security ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Such means may also be used in respect of persons who have agreed to that in writing , to protect their lives or property ( section DATE ) ) .

CARDINAL . NORP Only the following bodies may request the use of special means of surveillance and draw on the intelligence obtained thereby , in the spheres of their respective competencies : ( i ) the central “ Security ” and “ Police ” services of ORG , as well as the national and territorial directorates of that Ministry ; ( ii ) the “ Military Information ” and “ Military Police and Military CounterIntelligence ” services of ORG ; ( iii ) ORG ; ( iv ) ORG , ORG and the regional investigation services ; ( v ) the ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , the appellate prosecutor 's offices , ORG and the regional and regionalmilitary prosecutor 's offices ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The procedure for deploying special means of surveillance starts with a written application by the head of the respective service . The application must set out in detail the circumstances grounding the suspicion that a serious offence is being planned or committed or has been committed , so as to justify the use of surveillance . It must also fully describe the steps which have already been undertaken and the results of the hitherto inquiries or investigations . It has to contain information allowing the identification of the persons or objects to be subjected to surveillance , its duration , and the methods to be used . Finally , the application has to specify the name of the official to be informed of the results obtained ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The application is made to the president of ORG or of the respective regional court , or to a duly authorised deputy ( for military personnel the application is made to the president of the deputypresident of the respective military regional court ) who may issue a warrant ( section CARDINAL ) ) . If they refuse to issue a warrant , the application may be resubmitted to the president or a duly authorised deputy of the respective court of appeals ( section CARDINAL ) ) . The decision whether or not to issue a warrant must be taken immediately upon receipt of the application , and the originals of the application and of the warrant must be returned to the service which has made the application ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . After the warrant is issued , the Minister of ORG or a deputyminister designated in writing by the Minister makes a written order for the deployment of special means of surveillance ( section CARDINAL ) . In urgent cases , this step of the procedure may be skipped and the deployment may start immediately upon the issue of the warrant ( section CARDINAL ) . However , in that case the Minister or the deputyminister must be informed without delay ( ibid . ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ) of the ORG provides for an exception to the procedure outlined above in cases where there is an immediate risk that a serious intentional offence may be committed or where there is an immediate threat to national security . In such cases , the Minister of ORG or a deputyminister designated by the Minister may order the deployment of special means of surveillance without a judicial warrant . The deployment of these means must be discontinued if the warrant is not issued within TIME ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . In that case , the president or the vicepresident of the respective court decides whether the material obtained is to be kept or destroyed ( ibid . ) . He or she may thus retrospectively validate the use of special means of surveillance ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The Minister of ORG or a deputyminister authorised in writing may discontinue the use of special means of surveillance at any time before the planned end of the surveillance . In that case , the president or the vicepresident of the respective court must be informed in writing ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The only services which are authorised to deploy special means of surveillance are the “ Operative and Technical Information ” , the “ ORG ” and the “ Protection of the Means of Communication ” directorates of ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . However , ORG and the intelligence services of ORG may also deploy such means in the performance of their duties ( section CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Special means of surveillance may be used for a maximum of DATE ( section ORG ) ) . This time may , if necessary , be extended by the president or the vicepresident of the respective court for DATE , by a fresh warrant ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The use of special means of surveillance must be discontinued after the expiry of the timelimit set in the warrant , after the desired aims have been attained , or if the use of the means proves fruitless ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The intelligence obtained by such means must be recorded ( section CARDINAL ) . It must then , immediately after being obtained , be put down in writing by the service which has in fact deployed the means ( section GPE ) ) . The resulting document , which must faithfully reflect the contents of the recordings , is sent to the body which has requested the use of such means , possibly along with photographs and recordings ( section PERSON ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . While the special means of surveillance are still being used , the original recordings must be kept at the service which has deployed them ( section CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . If at the end of the period of authorised surveillance the sought intelligence has been obtained , the service which has deployed the means of surveillance draws up a note of physical evidence ( section DATE ) . The same is done if the sought intelligence has been obtained before the end of the period , pursuant to the written request of the body which has requested the measures ( section CARDINAL ) . Conversely , if the use of the means is fruitless , the body which has requested it advises in writing the service which deploys them that their use is to be discontinued . In that case no note of physical evidence is drawn up and the material obtained is destroyed ( section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The note of physical evidence must conform to the requirements of LAW ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . It has to be signed by the head of the service which has deployed the means ( section CARDINAL ) ) and refer to the application for their use , the order of the Minister or the deputyminister and the judicial warrant ( section CARDINAL ) ) . It has to specify the time and place of the use of the means , the types of devices and methods employed , the intelligence obtained , the textual reproduction of this intelligence , and the physical conditions under which the intelligence has been acquired ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The raw data is part of the record ( section CARDINAL ) ) . The evidence thus obtained is kept by ORG pending the opening of a criminal investigation . After the opening of an investigation the evidence is kept by the respective judicial authorities ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . The intelligence which is not used as evidence has to be destroyed by the directorate which has deployed the means within DATE and the destruction has to be recorded in TIME ( section ORG ) ) .

CARDINAL . NORP If the special means of surveillance have yielded results outside the scope of the initial application for their use and if these results come within the purview of other bodies allowed to request the use of such means ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the Minister of ORG or the duly authorised deputyminister must be notified immediately . He or she then decides how this intelligence is to be used ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The information obtained by using special means of surveillance may not be used for ends other than the prevention and detection of offences , or the gathering of evidence for the perpetration of offences , in accordance with the conditions and the manner specified by the law ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . All persons who come across information about the use of special means of surveillance under the conditions and according to the manner set out in the ORG , or intelligence obtained thereby , are under a duty not to disclose it ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The overall control over the use of special means of surveillance and the intelligence obtained thereby is entrusted to the Minister of ORG , who may issue instructions for the application of the ORG ( section GPE ) and paragraph CARDINAL of the concluding provisions of the LAW ) . The directorates which deploy these means may also carry out inspections to check whether special means of surveillance have been unlawfully used ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . To date , no instructions or regulations on the implementation of the ORG have been published in ORG .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , published in ORG on CARDINAL DATE ( реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL февруари DATE г. по конституционно дело № DATE г. , обн. , GPE , бр. CARDINAL от CARDINAL февруари DATE г. ) ORG rejected an application by the ORG to declare sections CARDINAL ) , CARDINAL , DATE and GPE ) of the ORG contrary to Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW .

CARDINAL . The court started by noting that the special means of surveillance regulated by the ORG amounted to interferences with private life , home and correspondence , all of which were permissible under ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . The court then proceeded to examine section CARDINAL ) of the ORG , which allows , under certain conditions , the use of special means of surveillance before the issue of judicial warrant . It held that LAW could not be read as requiring the prior issue of warrant in every case . The risk of abuse by the executive was reduced by the facts that the possibility of dispensing with prior judicial control was narrowly circumscribed and that immediate subsequent control was mandatory . This state of affairs was also compatible with LAW . In the court 's view , the ORG provided an even higher level of protection than these instruments .

CARDINAL . As regards section CARDINAL of the ORG , the court found that the possibility for the Minister of ORG to discontinue the use of special means of surveillance was not violative of LAW . While by LAW and section CARDINAL of the ORG the judiciary alone was empowered to authorise the use of such means , it was not the only branch of government which could order the termination of their use . The prerogative of the Minister did not therefore impinge on the independence of the judiciary .

CARDINAL . With regard to section CARDINAL of the ORG , the court held that its true meaning , when read in the context of the LAW as a whole , was not that the Minister of ORG could order the use of special means of surveillance anew if intelligence outside the scope of the initial request for their use was obtained . It was rather to be construed as allowing the Minister to decide to which authority to forward the intelligence already obtained . His powers in this respect were thus not in breach of LAW .

CARDINAL . Concerning section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the ORG , which entrusts the overall control over the system to the Minister of ORG , the court noted that it was impossible to empower another minister , let alone a nonexecutive body , with such functions , because that would disrupt the equality between , and the independence of , the CARDINAL branches of government . This followed also from paragraph CARDINAL of the concluding provisions of the ORG , which allowed the Minister to issue instructions for its application . Moreover , the logic of the system , which was apparent from the wording of LAW , required that the Minister be made responsible for controlling the use of the special means of surveillance until the moment when the intelligence obtained thereby was given to the judicial authorities . Therefore , the judicial control over the intelligence thus gathered had not been infringed and the resulting situation was compatible with LAW .
CARDINAL . CARDINAL judges dissented in part .

CARDINAL . One of them was of the opinion that section GPE ) of the ORG , which entrusts the control over the use of special means of surveillance to the Minister of ORG , was unconstitutional . In his view , this provision was not sufficiently precise and the powers it conferred to the ORG were not clearly delineated . It followed from the reading of the ORG as a whole that the Minister had powers in respect of both the use and the control over the use of special means of surveillance , which was inadmissible . The resulting lack of external control meant that section NORP ) was unconstitutional . When the law spoke about control over the system , it meant control over both its functioning as a whole and control in specific cases . To bestow controlling functions to the Minister , who also played a key part in the operation of the system , did not provide sufficient safeguards against the unwarranted use of special means of surveillance .

CARDINAL . The other dissenting judge considered that section CARDINAL ) of the ORG was unconstitutional , in that it allowed the Minister of ORG to order the use of special means of surveillance without the prior issue of judicial warrant , even in cases when their use would interfere with the freedom of correspondence or other communications . In his view , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW , which protects those freedoms , required prior judicial authorisation in all cases .

CARDINAL . Articles DATE of Code of Criminal Procedure of DATE ( “ the Code of DATE ” ) also regulated the use of special means of surveillance in the context of pending or impending criminal proceedings . They coincided almost verbatim with the provisions of the ORG . CARDINAL difference was that LAW § CARDINAL provided that the judge who issued the warrant had to be informed in writing when the use of the means was discontinued . If their use had been fruitless , he or she was to order the destruction of the material obtained .
CARDINAL . These provisions were superseded by Articles DATE of the Code of Criminal Procedure of DATE ( “ the Code of DATE ” ) , which entered into force on DATE .

CARDINAL . By Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of DATE , the investigation authorities may use special means of surveillance for investigating certain serious offences , which are exhaustively listed , if the relevant facts can not be established in another manner or if their establishment would be extremely difficult . Such means may be used for a maximum duration of DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) , which may , if needed , be extended by DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The procedure starts with a reasoned application made by the prosecutor in charge of the case ( LAW ) . The application must contain information about the offence under investigation , a description of the hitherto investigative steps and their results , information about the persons or objects which will be subjected to surveillance , the methods which will be used and the duration of the surveillance ( LAW ) . The surveillance warrant is issued under the hand of the president of the respective regional court or of a specifically authorised deputy ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . He or she must issue the warrant or refuse to do so immediately after receiving the application , and give reasons ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . If he or she refuses , the application may be resubmitted to the president of the respective court of appeals or a specifically authorised deputy ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . All applications and warrants are recorded in a special nonpublic register ( LAW ) . LAW DATE makes no provision for exceptions from this procedure save in the case of an undercover agent , who may , in urgent cases , start to operate pursuant to a prosecutor 's order , which must be confirmed by the respective judge within twentyfour TIME ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . After the issue of warrant the special means of surveillance are deployed in accordance with the provisions of the ORG ( LAW ) . The judge who issued the warrant must be informed in writing when the use of the means is discontinued . If their use has been fruitless , the judge orders the destruction of the material obtained ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The Protection of Classified Information Act of DATE ( „ Закон за защита на класифицираната информация “ – “ GPE ) , which was enacted in DATE and amended several times thereafter , provides a comprehensive framework for the creation , processing and storage of classified information , as well as the conditions and the procedure for providing access to such information ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . “ Classified information ” includes information which is a state or an official secret ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL defines a “ state secret ” as the “ information set out in Schedule No . CARDINAL [ to the LAW ] , the unregulated access to which could endanger or prejudice the interests of GPE and which relates to the national security , the defence , the foreign policy , or the protection of the constitutional order ” . Schedule No . CARDINAL to the LAW sets out a list of the categories of information which are liable to be classified as being a state secret . Thus , the information about special means of surveillance ( technical devices and/or the manner of their use ) used pursuant to the law is a state secret CARDINAL of part II of Schedule No . CARDINAL ) . So is the intelligence obtained as a result of the use of such means ( point CARDINAL of part II of Schedule No . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) defines an “ official secret ” as the “ information created or stored by state or local government authorities , which is not a state secret , but the unregulated access to which could have a negative impact on the interests of the ORG or on another legally protected interest ” . By section PERSON ) , the information classified as an “ official secret ” must be set out in a statute .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) lays down timelimits for protecting classified information . They vary from DATE for information marked as “ highly secret ” to DATE for information graded as an “ official secret ” . These timelimits may be extended , but by not more than the double of their original length ( section GPE ) ) . After the expiration of these timelimits the access to this information is effected in accordance with ORG ( section GPE ) ) .

CARDINAL . While the information is classified , it may be accessed only under certain conditions and by limited categories of persons , which must , in most cases , undergo a security check and obtain a security clearance ( sections CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that classified information may not be destroyed DATE after the expiration of the timelimit for its protection . The destruction of such information is possible only by virtue of a decision of ORG , made pursuant to the proposal of a special commission ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The ORG 's decision is subject to review by ORG ( section ORG ) ) .

CARDINAL . In a final judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL февруари DATE г. по адм. д. № CARDINAL/CARDINAL г. ) , given pursuant to an appeal by a person who had been refused information on whether the use of special means of surveillance had been authorised against him during the period CARDINAL January CARDINAL DATE , ORG held that while LAW enshrined the right to obtain information from a state body , that right was subject to limitations when , for instance , this information was a state or an official secret . It was apparent from LAW of the ORG that information about the use of special means of surveillance was not to be disclosed . The refusal to provide the requested information was thus compatible with LAW . The appellant 's argument that the refusal had been in breach of ORG was inapposite , because the material gathered pursuant to the ORG was outside the purview of ORG , as was the information whether the use of special means of surveillance had been authorised . The appellant 's further arguments that the information requested was not a state or an official secret within the meaning of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LOC and could moreover be divulged because of the expiry of the twoyear timelimit under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of that LAW were likewise unavailing , because that LAW did not apply retroactively .

CARDINAL . In a final judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( реш. № DATE от DATE г. по адм. д. № CARDINAL г. ) , given pursuant to an appeal by the same person as in case no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , concerning a further refusal to inform him of measures of covert surveillance against him , ORG held that his request for such information had properly been denied , because the information relating to special means of surveillance and the intelligence obtained by using them was a state secret within the meaning of section CARDINAL of the LOC and points CARDINAL and CARDINAL of part II of Schedule No . CARDINAL to GPE see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) . On the other hand , the eventual intelligence obtained pursuant to a warrant to use special means of surveillance , as well as the warrant itself , were an official secret within the meaning of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LOC . This followed also from the prohibition to divulge information about special means of surveillance laid down in CARDINAL of the ORG . The court went on to hold that the fact that the use of special means of surveillance could only be authorised by the presidents of the regional courts was sufficient to ensure independent judicial review of the activities of the executive and provided sufficient safeguards against unwarranted restriction on the citizens ' rights .

CARDINAL . Article LAW CARDINAL of LAW of DATE criminalises the use of information obtained through special means of surveillance for ends other than protecting national security or combating crime . The offence is aggravated if it has been committed by officials who have acquired or have come across this information in connection with the performance of their duties ( paragraph CARDINAL of that Article ) . It is furthermore an offence to unlawfully use information obtained through such means with a view to misleading a judicial authority ( LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW ) . There is no reported caselaw on the application of these texts .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG carried out a special inquiry on the use of special means of surveillance by ORG during DATE . While the inquiry was pending , the prosecutor in charge gave an interview , published in the daily ORG on DATE , in which he said that ORG was obstructing the inquiry . The report of the inquiry , which was finalised in DATE , was presented to ORG , ORG , ORG and ORG , but was apparently not made available to the general public . Nevertheless , some of the report 's findings were leaked to and reported by DATE newspapers . The report stated that the overall number of warrants for the use of special means of surveillance during DATE was CARDINAL , and that not including tapping of mobile phones . Out of these , CARDINAL or CARDINAL had subsequently supplied evidence for use in criminal proceedings . In CARDINAL cases special means of surveillance had been used against persons in respect of whom there had been no grounds for suspecting that they had committed a serious intentional offence . In a number of cases the orders for the deployment of such means had not been signed by the Minister of ORG himself , but by unknown persons on his behalf . In CARDINAL cases the dates of the applications for warrants and of the warrants themselves had been modified . In CARDINAL cases the warrants had not been assigned a number . In some cases the warrants had authorised measures implemented TIME before their issue . In CARDINAL cases the persons in respect of whom the warrants had been issued were not the persons under investigation .
CARDINAL . In an interview published by the DATE PERSON on DATE ORG said that during his DATE in office he had signed CARDINAL orders for the use of special means of surveillance .

CARDINAL . During DATE various newspaper publications reported a number of cases where it was alleged that the services of ORG had unlawfully used special means of surveillance . The allegations included illegal tapping of the telephones of opposition leaders , journalists , a former constitutional court judge , and other judges . In an interview published on DATE the Minister of ORG stated that “ a tremendously high number of wiretappings take place in GPE , but apparently for aims different from those of the criminal process ” .
